title: How to Bake Turkey Burgers

steps.headline: Combine the breadcrumbs and Greek yogurt.
steps.description: Start by making a panade by mixing your breadcrumbs and yogurt. If you don’t have plain Greek yogurt, you can substitute it with 1/3 cup (80 mL) of milk or stock. If you’re using white bread instead of store-bought breadcrumbs, tear up the slices and pulse the pieces in a food processor until you’ve formed coarse breadcrumbs. You can also toast the bread before tearing and pulsing it. A panade will make your patties super juicy, but you can skip this step if you want to cut some calories.

steps.headline: Add your flavorings.
steps.description: Flavor the panade by mixing in the shallot or onion, garlic, Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce, salt, black pepper, chili powder, cumin, ground mustard, and cayenne. The flavorings aren’t set in stone, so you can add or remove ingredients to suit your tastes. For instance, you could leave out the chili powder and cayenne if you can’t stand heat. You could also try adding 2 or 3 tablespoons of ranch dressing instead of the Worcestershire and soy sauces.

steps.headline: Mix in the ground turkey by hand.
steps.description: Mixing your ingredients by hand is better than using a spoon. If you use your hands, you can gently combine the ingredients evenly without over-mixing them, which can make your burgers tough. Don’t use too much pressure, and stop mixing when the panade and meat are evenly blended. Remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water for 30 seconds after handling raw turkey.

steps.headline: Form your patties.
steps.description: Divide your mixture into 4 evenly sized portions. Form them into 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick patties, then place them on a large plate or baking sheet. Make a dimple in each patty by lightly pressing your thumb into the center. The dimple will help prevent the centers from bulging when they cook.

steps.headline: Chill the patties in the fridge for an hour.
steps.description: Cover the plate or baking sheet tightly with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the patties for at least an hour so they’ll hold their shape better. If you have guests coming over, you can mix and form the patties in advance, then cook them when it’s time to eat.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.description: Before you turn the stove on, set up a rack in the middle of the oven. Make sure your oven comes to temperature before you bake your burgers.

steps.headline: Sear the burgers for 2 to 3 minutes per side.
steps.description: Get a skillet hot over medium-high heat, then add the olive oil. Add the patties to the skillet and sear them until they’re golden-brown, or about 2 to 3 minutes per side. Searing the patties first will give them a fabulous texture and enhance their flavor. However, you can skip this step if you want and just bake the patties for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer the patties to a baking sheet if your pan isn’t oven-safe.
steps.description: If you use a cast iron skillet or other oven-safe pan to sear your patties, you can just stick the entire pan in the oven. If your skillet isn’t oven-safe, use a spatula to transfer the patties to a baking sheet when they’re done searing.

steps.headline: Bake the patties for an additional 5 to 7 minutes.
steps.description: To accurately test for doneness, insert an instant read thermometer into a patty and check for a temperature of 160 to 165 °F (71 to 74 °C). A food thermometer is your best bet, but if you don’t have one, leave them in for the full 7 minutes. Peek through the oven window to make sure they don’t burn. Bake your patties for 30 minutes if you didn’t sear them first.

steps.headline: Top your hot patties with cheese, if desired.
steps.description: When you take your patties out of the oven, add slices of cheese if you’re in the mood for a cheeseburger. They’ll be hot enough to melt the cheese. American, provolone, swiss, and pepperjack are all great choices.

steps.headline: Let the patties rest for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Have patience! In addition to cooling them off, letting the patties rest will allow the juices to settle back into the meat. Your bites will be packed with more flavor if you rest the patties.

steps.headline: Place the patties on buns and add your garnishes.
steps.description: Use a spatula to transfer the patties onto buns. Serve them with garnishes of your choice, like lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions, ketchup, and mustard. Your patties will be bursting with flavor, so you won’t need to go overboard on the garnishes!

steps.headline: Store them in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.
steps.description: If you have leftovers or want to make your patties ahead, you can keep them in the fridge for 3 days. Cover them tightly with plastic wrap before putting them in the fridge. Reheat leftover patties in the oven instead of the microwave for better quality.

text: Forming the Patties Combine the breadcrumbs and Greek yogurt. Start by making a panade by mixing your breadcrumbs and yogurt. If you don’t have plain Greek yogurt, you can substitute it with 1/3 cup (80 mL) of milk or stock. If you’re using white bread instead of store-bought breadcrumbs, tear up the slices and pulse the pieces in a food processor until you’ve formed coarse breadcrumbs. You can also toast the bread before tearing and pulsing it. A panade will make your patties super juicy, but you can skip this step if you want to cut some calories. Add your flavorings. Flavor the panade by mixing in the shallot or onion, garlic, Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce, salt, black pepper, chili powder, cumin, ground mustard, and cayenne. The flavorings aren’t set in stone, so you can add or remove ingredients to suit your tastes. For instance, you could leave out the chili powder and cayenne if you can’t stand heat. You could also try adding 2 or 3 tablespoons of ranch dressing instead of the Worcestershire and soy sauces. Mix in the ground turkey by hand. Mixing your ingredients by hand is better than using a spoon. If you use your hands, you can gently combine the ingredients evenly without over-mixing them, which can make your burgers tough. Don’t use too much pressure, and stop mixing when the panade and meat are evenly blended. Remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water for 30 seconds after handling raw turkey. Form your patties. Divide your mixture into 4 evenly sized portions. Form them into 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick patties, then place them on a large plate or baking sheet. Make a dimple in each patty by lightly pressing your thumb into the center. The dimple will help prevent the centers from bulging when they cook. Chill the patties in the fridge for an hour. Cover the plate or baking sheet tightly with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the patties for at least an hour so they’ll hold their shape better. If you have guests coming over, you can mix and form the patties in advance, then cook them when it’s time to eat. Searing and Baking the Patties Preheat your oven to 375 °F (191 °C). Before you turn the stove on, set up a rack in the middle of the oven. Make sure your oven comes to temperature before you bake your burgers. Sear the burgers for 2 to 3 minutes per side. Get a skillet hot over medium-high heat, then add the olive oil. Add the patties to the skillet and sear them until they’re golden-brown, or about 2 to 3 minutes per side. Searing the patties first will give them a fabulous texture and enhance their flavor. However, you can skip this step if you want and just bake the patties for 30 minutes. Transfer the patties to a baking sheet if your pan isn’t oven-safe. If you use a cast iron skillet or other oven-safe pan to sear your patties, you can just stick the entire pan in the oven. If your skillet isn’t oven-safe, use a spatula to transfer the patties to a baking sheet when they’re done searing. Bake the patties for an additional 5 to 7 minutes. To accurately test for doneness, insert an instant read thermometer into a patty and check for a temperature of 160 to 165 °F (71 to 74 °C). A food thermometer is your best bet, but if you don’t have one, leave them in for the full 7 minutes. Peek through the oven window to make sure they don’t burn. Bake your patties for 30 minutes if you didn’t sear them first. Assembling Your Burgers Top your hot patties with cheese, if desired. When you take your patties out of the oven, add slices of cheese if you’re in the mood for a cheeseburger. They’ll be hot enough to melt the cheese. American, provolone, swiss, and pepperjack are all great choices. Let the patties rest for 5 minutes. Have patience! In addition to cooling them off, letting the patties rest will allow the juices to settle back into the meat. Your bites will be packed with more flavor if you rest the patties. Place the patties on buns and add your garnishes. Use a spatula to transfer the patties onto buns. Serve them with garnishes of your choice, like lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions, ketchup, and mustard. Your patties will be bursting with flavor, so you won’t need to go overboard on the garnishes! Store them in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. If you have leftovers or want to make your patties ahead, you can keep them in the fridge for 3 days. Cover them tightly with plastic wrap before putting them in the fridge. Reheat leftover patties in the oven instead of the microwave for better quality. Finished.
sentences: Forming the Patties Combine the breadcrumbs and Greek yogurt.
Start by making a panade by mixing your breadcrumbs and yogurt.
If you don’t have plain Greek yogurt, you can substitute it with 1/3 cup (80 mL) of milk or stock.
If you’re using white bread instead of store-bought breadcrumbs, tear up the slices and pulse the pieces in a food processor until you’ve formed coarse breadcrumbs.
You can also toast the bread before tearing and pulsing it.
A panade will make your patties super juicy, but you can skip this step if you want to cut some calories.
Add your flavorings.
Flavor the panade by mixing in the shallot or onion, garlic, Worcestershire sauce, soy sauce, salt, black pepper, chili powder, cumin, ground mustard, and cayenne.
The flavorings aren’t set in stone, so you can add or remove ingredients to suit your tastes.
For instance, you could leave out the chili powder and cayenne if you can’t stand heat.
You could also try adding 2 or 3 tablespoons of ranch dressing instead of the Worcestershire and soy sauces.
Mix in the ground turkey by hand.
Mixing your ingredients by hand is better than using a spoon.
If you use your hands, you can gently combine the ingredients evenly without over-mixing them, which can make your burgers tough.
Don’t use too much pressure, and stop mixing when the panade and meat are evenly blended.
Remember to wash your hands with soap and hot water for 30 seconds after handling raw turkey.
Form your patties.
Divide your mixture into 4 evenly sized portions.
Form them into 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick patties, then place them on a large plate or baking sheet.
Make a dimple in each patty by lightly pressing your thumb into the center.
The dimple will help prevent the centers from bulging when they cook.
Chill the patties in the fridge for an hour.
Cover the plate or baking sheet tightly with plastic wrap.
Refrigerate the patties for at least an hour so they’ll hold their shape better.
If you have guests coming over, you can mix and form the patties in advance, then cook them when it’s time to eat.
Searing and Baking the Patties Preheat your oven to 375 °F (191 °C).
Before you turn the stove on, set up a rack in the middle of the oven.
Make sure your oven comes to temperature before you bake your burgers.
Sear the burgers for 2 to 3 minutes per side.
Get a skillet hot over medium-high heat, then add the olive oil.
Add the patties to the skillet and sear them until they’re golden-brown, or about 2 to 3 minutes per side.
Searing the patties first will give them a fabulous texture and enhance their flavor.
However, you can skip this step if you want and just bake the patties for 30 minutes.
Transfer the patties to a baking sheet if your pan isn’t oven-safe.
If you use a cast iron skillet or other oven-safe pan to sear your patties, you can just stick the entire pan in the oven.
If your skillet isn’t oven-safe, use a spatula to transfer the patties to a baking sheet when they’re done searing.
Bake the patties for an additional 5 to 7 minutes.
To accurately test for doneness, insert an instant read thermometer into a patty and check for a temperature of 160 to 165 °F (71 to 74 °C).
A food thermometer is your best bet, but if you don’t have one, leave them in for the full 7 minutes.
Peek through the oven window to make sure they don’t burn.
Bake your patties for 30 minutes if you didn’t sear them first.
Assembling Your Burgers Top your hot patties with cheese, if desired.
When you take your patties out of the oven, add slices of cheese if you’re in the mood for a cheeseburger.
They’ll be hot enough to melt the cheese.
American, provolone, swiss, and pepperjack are all great choices.
Let the patties rest for 5 minutes.
Have patience!
In addition to cooling them off, letting the patties rest will allow the juices to settle back into the meat.
Your bites will be packed with more flavor if you rest the patties.
Place the patties on buns and add your garnishes.
Use a spatula to transfer the patties onto buns.
Serve them with garnishes of your choice, like lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions, ketchup, and mustard.
Your patties will be bursting with flavor, so you won’t need to go overboard on the garnishes!
Store them in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.
If you have leftovers or want to make your patties ahead, you can keep them in the fridge for 3 days.
Cover them tightly with plastic wrap before putting them in the fridge.
Reheat leftover patties in the oven instead of the microwave for better quality.
Finished.
